name: The Essex, Vermont's Culinary Resort & Spa

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My girlfriend and I both love to cook, so we decided to combine our love of travel and cooking into a long weekend getaway. She saw a special offer on Travelzoo for discounted rooms at the Inn at Essex and we signed on for two cooking classes. We were totally impressed with the Inn at Essex. The staff, the food served in their two restaurants, and the cooking classes were outstanding! We found a professional staff, clean and comfortable room, and fantastic training kitchen for our cooking classes. If you love to cook or want to learn more about cooking, then check out the Inn at Essex and the New England Culinary Institute located there. I've been to other cooking schools, but they tend to be overcrowded. They limit the class size to 6 here, which is perfect. Everyone can participate hands-on, ask many questions of the instructor, and have a lot of fun learning, cooking, and eating! I highly recommend the Inn at Essex and will return there this spring, for sure!
reviews.title: An Inn For Foodies!

likes.disliked: — A bit expensive...but it IS worth it!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We purchased an AARP show package that included a cooking class and 2 nights in an upgraded (ie gas fireplace) room for approx $300.00. The cooking class was great fun (and we learned a great deal), the food at all meals was creative and delicious (which I would expect from culinary students), and the staff was helpful and accommodating. The room was beautifully decorated, had a good closet, and was on the larger side. Some nice touches, such as Green Mountain coffee in the morning, hot cider at night, and an Internet connection in the lobby. One word of caution, however. Check ahead of time to confirm all charges: On checking out, we were charged an extra $41 as a gratuity to the cooking teacher. When I questioned this, the charge was removed. When I got home and rechecked the bill, I noticed a discrepancy between the 'show' price and what I had actually been charged. An email quickly cleared up the discrepancy and the amount was returned to my credit card within 24 hrs.
reviews.title: Excellent food, lovely room, pleasant staff

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: All in all, a wonderful weekend and a great way to recharge our batteries before the frantic Thanksgiving rush begins.
reviews.title: Great Food

reviews.text: We chose to stay at the Inn at Essex on our return visit to Vermont in late September 2007. We had stayed there in August 2001 and enjoyed the food and the pool. Even though we had been there before we still had difficulty finding the hotel. Fortunately, on arrival the desk staff provide instructions for getting to Burlington and for finding your way back to the hotel. Six years later the food is still excellent but there are places where the hotel is showing its age. The elevator looks tatty and the air-conditioning unit in our room was corroded (although it worked perfectly). Also the extractor fan in the bathroom didn't work and this fault was not rectified even though we reported it. However, these minor faults did not spoil our stay. The food and service were as good as we remembered them to be from six years ago. The room was clean and tidy. The desk staff were friendly and helpful and there is a computer with Internet connection for guest use in the lobby. We would certainly come back to the Inn at Essex again.
reviews.title: pleasant enough but overpriced....

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My wife and I returned recently from a two night stay at the Inn at Essex, having booked last-minute one of the packages featured on the inn's website. For the most part, our stay was pleasant enough. We were upgraded to a suite in the "manor", which featured a separate living area and kitchenette as well as an amusingly small gas fireplace. While the bed was fantastically comfortable, the room (and the entire inn for that matter) had a rather generic feel to it, more akin to what you would expect from a large chain hotel than a high-priced country inn. As far as we could tell, there was nothing particularly distinctive about the way our room had been decorated. Note that unlike other people posting on this site, we didn't have any problems with the service: everyone we dealt with was professional and courteous.
reviews.title: Quaint and comfortable

reviews.text: Stayed here for a few days while attending a business meeting. The meeting room was in a sort of basement(?) at the end of an underground tunnel(?) In addition to the inconvenient location of the meeting rooms, we were constantly distracted by the gardener mowing the lawn.
reviews.title: Give it a miss!

reviews.text: We booked the Vermont Gateway package, which included: one night stay in a regular room, 3 course dinner at the Butler's, the hotel restaurant operated by students of the New England Culinary Institute, a continental breakfast and a bottle of sparkling wine in the room upon arrival. We upgraded the package to get a nicer room with a fireplace and whirlpool.
reviews.title: A Lovely Inn

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed on a 3 night package the first week of October. I'd have to say the Inn was nice, but nothing great. The room was kind of basic, not a lot of decorations, but OK. I guess I was thinking it would be more like a bed and breakfast, but it is an Inn. (You don't get a breakfast) They seem to cater to both conferences and also bus tours - there was buses arriving and leaving (get a room away from the parking lot if you want to sleep in) everyday and also a conference going on in the building we were in.
reviews.title: OK Place to stay - great restaurant

description: Nestled on 18 acres between the vistas of the Green Mountains and the splendor of Lake Champlain, The Essex is Vermont’s Culinary Resort & Spa. As the Burlington area’s only AAA Four Diamond hotel, The Essex is a true destination, offering a full-service Spa and Fitness Center, cooking classes in the J.K. Adams and Chef's Kitchens of Cook Academy, and our two award-winning restaurants-- all of which perfectly complement our classic accommodations.The Essex is the premier choice for your next group event and is the perfect Vermont wedding destination for dozens of happy couples tying the knot each year. From our own Vermont Tennis Vacations to our wine list, ranked among the best in the world, The Essex offers you an experience unlike any other resort in New England. ...a true Recipe for Relaxation.
